text: Really getting into metaprogramming, starting to click! Loving it.

text: Are you working on a PR for dataframesmeta?

text: Thinking more of a separate package that uses dataframesmeta as a dependency. Thinking it will be too idiosyncratic to be a PR. But happy for it to be heavily drawn on if others find it useful.

text: Kind of a decade long goal of finding/stylizing another data management/wrangling tool which is as accessible to new users as Stata.

text:
I really think DataFramesMeta will be close, soon! Once we get `where` and `@byrow` sorted  out in DataFrames, I think `@chain` with `@transform!` is very close.

Please file an issue with your more detailed design decisions when you finish working on this package. I don't want people to feel like they have to re-invent the wheel.

is very close.

text:
Right now I have:
```n = 7
x = DataFrame(A=1:n, B=rand(1:2, n), C=rand(1:2, n))
@mount x
@make E = :C + :B
@make (E = round.(:A .^ .5, digits = 1)) iff(:B .< :A .- 1)
@make by(B) ( H = round(mean(:A),digits = 1)) iff(:A .> 2)```
Producing
```7 rows × 5 columns
    A	B	C	E	H
    Int64	Int64	Int64	Float64?	Float64?
1	1	2	2	4.0	missing
2	2	2	2	4.0	missing
3	3	2	1	3.0	3.5
4	4	2	2	2.0	3.5
5	5	1	2	2.2	6.0
6	6	1	2	2.4	6.0
7	7	1	2	2.6	6.0```

How is that different from DataFramesMeta with `@chain` though?

```julia> @chain x begin 
       @transform E = :C + :B
       @transform(
           E = :A .^ .5, 
           F = :A .^ 2, 
           G = 1, 
           status = "Map 1"
       )
       groupby(:B); @transform H = mean(:A)
       end
7×8 DataFrame
 Row │ A      B      C      E        F      G      status  H       
     │ Int64  Int64  Int64  Float64  Int64  Int64  String  Float64 
─────┼─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   1 │     1      1      2  1.0          1      1  Map 1       3.6
   2 │     2      1      2  1.41421      4      1  Map 1       3.6
   3 │     3      2      2  1.73205      9      1  Map 1       5.0
   4 │     4      1      2  2.0         16      1  Map 1       3.6
   5 │     5      1      2  2.23607     25      1  Map 1       3.6
   6 │     6      1      2  2.44949     36      1  Map 1       3.6
   7 │     7      2      2  2.64575     49      1  Map 1       5.0```

elements.text: How is that different from DataFramesMeta with

text: the only thing missing is the `@iff`, bits. Which doesn't need a "decade-long" project and a new package

text: That is why I said it is probably be too idiosyncratic. I know, I know you guys/gals who have programming in your blood find `@chain` and other things of this sort second nature. But if you want to teach data management and analysis to medical doctors or economists or whatever who spent years honing their skills in their field, they are going to find the above both confusing and unnecessarily complicated. It will hopefully be more clear as I add functionality.

text:
I understand that the above may be confusing. But the differences between the two approaches don't seem very meaningful to me at the moment. For reference, I am an economist and have spent plenty of time teaching new comers data-cleaning.

It's a bummer that you think the `@chain` approach is too complicated. To be clear, this is the same approach used by `dplyr`, which plenty of new-comers can pick up easily.

That said, I look forward to seeing more of your design choices! I hope that I can learn from your package and some of your features can be merged into DataFramesMeta.
